header_summary:
Recent discussions in blockchain development have spotlighted the evolution of Bitcoin's scripting languages, particularly the shift from tapscript to tarscript and the introduction of Simplicity, which aims to maintain computational simplicity by avoiding NP-hard scenarios in block assembly. Russell O'Connor et al. elaborate on how tarscript's dual constraints of sigops and varops introduce complexity, contrasting with Simplicity's unified budget mechanism for cost calculations ([source](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/CAMZUoK=1B=LQxkhPsbx22wAFkgsKT20J-6+r-Pa0AAh9AMgo4g@mail.gmail.com/T/#md729a0aee56f6e493967b384f1ba6bb154df8482)).

In another vein, ajtowns discusses the nuances of benchmarking blockchain transaction validation, emphasizing the efficiency gains possible through caching mechanisms and parallel processing. This conversation also touches on the potential of new opcodes to enhance blockchain's capacity for complex operations, such as zero-knowledge proofs, under current constraints ([source](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/benchmarking-bitcoin-script-evaluation-for-the-varops-budget-great-script-restoration/2094/6)).

ZmnSCPxj introduces the Shared-spending Inter-Protocol Framework, a novel approach to simplifying Bitcoin transaction management by enabling automatic batching and Replace-By-Fee mechanisms, thus enhancing user experience and protocol flexibility. The framework's design ensures resilience and reliability, even across system restarts, by requiring pre-registration of protocols and using persistent storage for pending requests ([source](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/private-key-handover/2098/2)).

Lastly, theStack provides insights into the performance of ECDSA signature validation across different processor architectures, revealing significant improvements in arm64 systems compared to mixed results on x86-64 architectures. This analysis, illustrated through a specialized branch on GitHub, highlights the architectural dependencies of cryptographic operations and their optimization over time ([source](https://github.com/theStack/secp256k1-plugbench/tree/plot-xtime-ylog)).

recent_posts.title: Benchmarking Bitcoin Script Evaluation for the Varops Budget (GSR)
recent_posts.summary:
- Russell O'Connor discusses Bitcoin's scripting challenges with new script versions.
- He compares Simplicity's single constraint approach to tarscript V2's complex dual constraints.
- Highlighting a debate on balancing blockchain functionality and computational simplicity.
contributors: Benchmarking Bitcoin Script Evaluation for the Varops Budget (GSR) 'Julian'

recent_posts.title: Benchmarking Bitcoin Script Evaluation for the Varops Budget (Great Script Restoration)
recent_posts.summary:
- The discussion criticizes using worst-case scenarios for average blockchain performance benchmarks.
- It reveals signature verification can be optimized through caching, unlike other operations.
- The talk explores leveraging multi-threading and new opcodes to improve blockchain validation efficiency.

recent_posts.title: Private Key Handover
recent_posts.summary:
- The Shared-spending Framework enhances Bitcoin wallet management with automatic batching and RBF.
- It streamlines transactions using `fund_output` and `spend_input` functions, improving user and developer experience.
- Its resilience and reliability are ensured by protocol pre-registration and persistent storage, supporting system restarts.

recent_posts.title: Comparing the performance of ECDSA signature validation in OpenSSL vs. libsecp256k1 over the last decade
recent_posts.summary:
- The study highlights ECDSA signature validation performance across different CPUs, emphasizing arm64 over x86-64.
- A specialized GitHub branch visualizes these performance comparisons, revealing significant improvements.
- The research suggests architectural dependencies in cryptographic operations and highlights the importance of data visualization.

active_posts.title: [BIP Proposal] Reduced Data Temporary Softfork
authors: [BIP Proposal] Reduced Data Temporary Softfork dathonohm
active_posts.summary:
- The proposal limits data on Bitcoin Core v30 to emphasize its use as currency.
- It offers a year-long temporary soft fork with proactive and reactive activation methods.
- Community support and technical contributions are crucial for quick and effective implementation.

active_posts.title: Motion to Activate BIP 3
active_posts.summary:
- BIP 3 advanced to "Proposed" in March 2025, with improvements and a GitHub pull request since April.
- The proposal has significant support, evidenced by over 600 comments and endorsements through ACKs.
- Amendments include SPDX License Expressions adoption and a clarified process for BIP publication and acceptance.

active_posts.title: BIP54 implementation and test vectors
authors: BIP54 implementation and test vectors 'Antoine Poinsot'
active_posts.summary:
- Antoine Poinsot updated on BIP54, focusing on its development and comprehensive testing.
- BIP54 test vectors cover transaction sigops limits and witness-stripped transaction size restrictions.
- The initiative seeks feedback to ensure BIP54 aligns with Bitcoin protocol enhancements across platforms.

active_posts.title: BIP352: PSBT support
active_posts.summary:
- Sending and spending silent payments in PSBTs could enhance transaction privacy and security.
- A draft BIP proposes an `OutputGenerator` role for easier silent payment integration.
- Despite possible benefits, concerns about the security of new cryptographic methods remain.

active_posts.title: P2share: how to turn any network (or testnet!) into a bitcoin miner
active_posts.summary:
- The p2share network reshapes bitcoin mining rewards distribution, offering shares to miners.
- It uniquely awards the entire bitcoin block reward to one randomly selected shareholder.
- This framework aims for fairness, efficiency, and decentralization, potentially impacting future blockchain developments.

active_posts.title: BIP352 private key formats
active_posts.summary:
- An exploration into enhancing Bitcoin payment solutions with Schnorr Protocol integration is discussed.
- The approach includes defining a string format for key combinations to facilitate SP-based transactions.
- Modifications to the Human-Readable Part of addresses aim to improve security and functionality in SP transactions.

today_in_history_posts.title: Towards a singular payment protocol
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- A new payment protocol proposal supports multiple currencies and blockchains, not tied to any specific one.
- It allows for multi-currency transactions, fee flexibility, with trusted parties handling valuation.
- The aim is enhancing functionality across wallets and blockchains, with eventual development into a BIP.
contributors: [bitcoin-dev] Towards a singular payment protocol ee

today_in_history_posts.title: [DRAFT] BOLT 13(?): WatchTower protocol
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Sergi Delgado Segura and Rusty Russell discuss Lightning's WatchTower protocol.
- They explore message types, requirements, and the accountability QoS system.
- Discussions include encryption, payment modes for WatchTower, and storage reduction techniques.

today_in_history_posts.title: CTV, APO, CAT activity on signet
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- BIPs 118, 119, and 347 introduce key updates to Bitcoin's scripting, enabling advanced transactions.
- APO use mainly targets coinbase transactions and reusing signatures, while CTV facilitates complex spend conditions.
- OP_CAT, under BIP 347, sees extensive application, outperforming APO/CTV in transaction volume due to integration into key processes.
